fever.description: A fever is when your body temperature is higher than your normal average temperature. It’s your body’s response to fighting an infection or illness.
symptoms: Chills, feeling cold, shivering and shaking
On and off or constant sweating
additional_symptoms_in_children: Lack of appetite — not eating and drinking well
Earache or pulling at their ears
treatment: Combination medications such as Asozen Forte

cough.description: A cough is a reflex action to clear your airways of mucus, irritants, or foreign particles.
causes: Viral infections like the common cold or flu
treatment: Steam inhalation, honey, and warm fluids
Medications like dextromethorphan, guaifenesin, or bromhexine

cold.description: The common cold is a viral infection affecting the upper respiratory tract, particularly the nose and throat.
causes: Touching contaminated surfaces and then touching the face
treatment: Over-the-counter medications like acetaminophen for pain relief
Cough syrups or throat lozenges for sore throat

headache.description: A headache is pain or discomfort in the head or face, which may vary in intensity and duration.
symptoms: Pain or pressure in the forehead, temples, or back of the head
treatment: Pain relievers like acetaminophen or ibuprofen
Avoiding triggers like bright lights or loud noises for migraine sufferers

stomach_ache.description: Stomach ache refers to pain or discomfort in the abdomen, often related to digestive issues.
symptoms: Cramping or dull pain in the abdomen
treatment: Over-the-counter pain relievers for menstrual cramps
Avoiding trigger foods in cases of IBS

allergy.description: An allergy is an immune response to a substance that’s not typically harmful to the body, like pollen, food, or pet dander.
causes: Exposure to allergens such as pollen, dust mites, pet dander, or specific foods

diabetes.description: Diabetes is a chronic disease that affects how your body turns food into energy.

asthma.description: Asthma is a condition in which your airways narrow and swell and may produce extra mucus.

blood_pressure.description: Blood pressure (BP) is the pressure of circulating blood against the walls of blood vessels. High blood pressure, also known as hypertension, is a condition where this pressure is consistently too high, increasing the risk of heart disease and stroke.
symptoms: Often no symptoms in early stages (silent condition)
treatment: Lifestyle changes, such as a healthy diet and regular exercise
Medications like ACE inhibitors, beta-blockers, and diuretics

cancer.description: Cancer is a group of diseases characterized by the uncontrolled growth and spread of abnormal cells. It can occur in almost any tissue or organ in the body. If left untreated, cancer can spread to other parts of the body, leading to severe complications.
causes: Chronic infections (e.g., HPV, Hepatitis B or C)

paracetamol.description: Paracetamol (also known as acetaminophen) is a common over-the-counter medication used to relieve pain and reduce fever. It is widely used for headaches, muscle aches, arthritis, back pain, toothaches, and colds.
causes: Used to manage pain and fever from various conditions, including headaches, toothaches, and colds.
treatment: Pain relief for mild to moderate pain

ibuprofen.description: Ibuprofen is a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) that is used to reduce fever, pain, and inflammation. It is commonly used for conditions like arthritis, muscle pain, and menstrual cramps.
causes: Used for conditions involving pain and inflammation, such as arthritis, muscle pain, and menstrual cramps.
treatment: Pain relief for moderate to severe pain

aspirin.description: Aspirin is an anti-inflammatory, analgesic, and antipyretic drug commonly used to treat pain, fever, and inflammation. It is also used for preventing heart attacks, strokes, and blood clots.
causes: Used for pain, inflammation, and fever management. Also used for heart and stroke prevention.
treatment: Pain relief for headaches, arthritis, and other conditions
Prevention of heart attacks and strokes in at-risk patients

injury.description: An accident injury refers to damage or harm caused to the body as a result of an unexpected event, such as a fall, vehicle crash, or other physical trauma. These injuries can range from minor cuts and bruises to more severe injuries like fractures, concussions, or internal bleeding.
symptoms: Pain or tenderness at the site of injury
Difficulty moving a limb or joint
Nausea or vomiting (in case of head injuries)
Shortness of breath or chest pain (for severe injuries)
treatment: First aid (cleaning wounds, stopping bleeding, immobilizing injured area)
Ice packs for swelling and pain relief
Pain relievers like ibuprofen or paracetamol
Rest and elevation of the injured area
Bandages or splints for fractures or sprains
Medical treatment (such as stitches, casts, or surgery) for severe injuries
Rehabilitation therapy for recovery after significant injuries

blood clot.description: A blood clot is a thickened, gel-like mass of blood that forms when blood cells and proteins stick together. While blood clotting is a natural process that prevents excessive bleeding after injury, abnormal blood clots can form in the veins or arteries, leading to dangerous conditions such as deep vein thrombosis (DVT), pulmonary embolism, or stroke.
symptoms: Swelling and pain in the affected area (commonly legs for DVT)
Redness or warmth in the skin over the clot
Shortness of breath (in case of pulmonary embolism)
Chest pain (in case of pulmonary embolism)
Dizziness or fainting (in case of stroke or severe clots)
causes: Prolonged immobility (sitting or lying down for long periods)
Injury or trauma to blood vessels
Certain medical conditions (e.g., cancer, heart disease)
Use of birth control pills or hormone therapy
Family history of blood clotting disorders
treatment: Blood thinners (anticoagulants) like warfarin, heparin, or newer anticoagulants
Thrombolytic therapy (clot-busting medications) for severe clots
Compression stockings to reduce swelling and prevent clot formation
Surgical removal of the clot (in some cases)
Lifestyle changes to prevent clot recurrence, such as increased physical activity and weight management

body pains.description: Body pain refers to discomfort or aching throughout the body, often caused by muscle or joint strain, illness, or injury. It can be a symptom of various conditions like fibromyalgia, viral infections (e.g., flu), or overuse of muscles. It can be localized to specific areas or generalized across the body.
symptoms: Generalized aching or soreness in the muscles or joints
Tenderness to touch in certain areas
Pain that worsens with movement or activity
causes: Chronic conditions like fibromyalgia, arthritis, or lupus
Injury or trauma to muscles or bones
treatment: Over-the-counter pain relievers like paracetamol or ibuprofen
Hot or cold compresses to reduce pain and inflammation
Gentle stretching or physical therapy for muscle-related pain
Treatment for underlying conditions (e.g., managing arthritis or fibromyalgia)
